articles.headline: Forging a Hot Link to the Farmer Who Grows the Food
articles.snippet: A flour miller in Washington State turns to the Internet to revive once-strong ties between consumers and farmers.
articles.abstract: A flour miller in Washington State turns to the Internet to revive once-strong ties between consumers and farmers.
articles.lead_paragraph: America, meet your farmer.
articles.byline: By Brad Stone and Matt Richtel

articles.headline: Helping Out With Cash: A Delicate Art
articles.snippet: People who want to financially help those close to them might first ask themselves some questions on the best way to do it.
articles.abstract: People who want to financially help those close to them might first ask themselves some questions on the best way to do it.
articles.lead_paragraph: It was the idea of her friend’s children riding around in the back seat of an uninsured vehicle that finally convinced Mishiko Flores that she had to do something to help.

articles.headline: Goldman Bailed Out 2 Executives
articles.snippet: The executives, both shareholders, were caught short of cash, and the bank was worried that a big share sale would alarm investors.
articles.abstract: The executives, both shareholders, were caught short of cash, and the bank was worried that a big share sale would alarm investors.
articles.lead_paragraph: The financial giant Goldman Sachs spent tens of millions of dollars to bail out two senior executives last fall who were short on cash, according to the bank’s proxy statement filed on Friday.

articles.headline: U.S. Expected to Give More Money to Automakers
articles.snippet: The administration is expected to impose a strict deadline for bondholders and union workers to make concessions.
articles.abstract: The administration is expected to impose a strict deadline for bondholders and union workers to make concessions.
articles.lead_paragraph: DETROIT  The Obama administration will probably extend more short-term aid to General Motors and Chrysler on Monday, but will impose a strict deadline for bondholders and union workers to make concessions that would help the ailing automakers become viable businesses and avert bankruptcy.
articles.byline: By Bill Vlasic and Sheryl Gay Stolberg

articles.headline: Amid Abuse in Brazil, Abortion Debate Flares
articles.snippet: The case of a 9-year-old who had an abortion after saying she was raped has revived a debate over abortion rights.
articles.abstract: The case of a 9-year-old who had an abortion after saying she was raped has revived a debate over abortion rights.
articles.lead_paragraph: SÃO PAULO, Brazil  The waiting room at Pérola Byington Hospital resembles a small day care center many days. Young girls play on the cold tile floors or rock hyperactively in plastic chairs, while their mothers stare pensively at the red digital readout on a wall, signaling their place in line.

articles.headline: This Time, Geithner’s Plan for Banks Makes Sense
articles.snippet: The plan to deal with toxic assets could, in the best case, make our banks a little healthier and a little better able to extend credit.
articles.abstract: The plan to deal with toxic assets could, in the best case, make our banks a little healthier and a little better able to extend credit.
articles.lead_paragraph: Will it work?

articles.headline: Despite Red Flags About Judges, a Kickback Scheme Flourished
articles.snippet: Residents of Luzerne County, Pa., wondered what led two judges to send juveniles to detention centers in return for money.
articles.abstract: Residents of Luzerne County, Pa., wondered what led two judges to send juveniles to detention centers in return for money.
articles.lead_paragraph: WILKES-BARRE, Pa. — Things were different in the Luzerne County juvenile courtroom, and everyone knew it. Proceedings on average took less than two minutes. Detention center workers were told in advance how many juveniles to expect at the end of each day — even before hearings to determine their innocence or guilt. Lawyers told families not to bother hiring them. They would not be allowed to speak anyway.

articles.headline: Do New Bulbs Save Energy if They Don’t Work?
articles.snippet: Consumers who are trying new compact fluorescent bulbs say they sometimes fail to work, or wear out early.
articles.abstract: Consumers who are trying new compact fluorescent bulbs say they sometimes fail to work, or wear out early.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — It sounds like such a simple thing to do: buy some new light bulbs, screw them in, save the planet.

articles.headline: White House Debate Led to Plan to Widen Afghan Effort
articles.snippet: The administration’s plan for Afghanistan followed a fierce debate in which the vice president urged caution against a quagmire while military advisers argued for more troops.
articles.abstract: The administration’s plan for Afghanistan followed a fierce debate in which the vice president urged caution against a quagmire while military advisers argued for more troops.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  President Obama’s plan to widen United States involvement in Afghanistan came after an internal debate in which Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. warned against getting into a political and military quagmire, while military advisers argued that the Afghanistan war effort could be imperiled without even more troops.
articles.byline: By Helene Cooper and Eric Schmitt

articles.headline: Detroit Faces Its Critics With Anger and Tears
articles.snippet: Detroiters said they wished they could persuade the country why G.M. and Chrysler, and by extension the city, deserved to be saved.
articles.abstract: Detroiters said they wished they could persuade the country why G.M. and Chrysler, and by extension the city, deserved to be saved.
articles.lead_paragraph: DETROIT — Just across the city line, AJ’s Music Cafe is hosting a 10-day marathon of live music called the Assembly Line Concert, meant to both help auto workers and set a world record for an uninterrupted performance.

articles.headline: Obama’s Man on the Budget: Just 40 and Going Like 60
articles.snippet: Like any budget director, Peter R. Orszag is a “supernerd.” But his political connections and policy ambitions suggest he is driven by more than his epic caffeine consumption.
articles.abstract: Like any budget director, Peter R. Orszag is a “supernerd.” But his political connections and policy ambitions suggest he is driven by more than his epic caffeine consumption.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — At 6 in the morning, Peter R. Orszag is racing: across wet pavement for a 35-minute run, into a shower and a suit, and through a living room that looks rather like an office, the walls painted presidential gold and hung with pictures of federal monuments.

articles.headline: Vast Spy System Loots Computers in 103 Countries
articles.snippet: Researchers said that the spying, which infiltrated the offices of the Dalai Lama, was controlled from computers based almost exclusively in China.
articles.abstract: Researchers said that the spying, which infiltrated the offices of the Dalai Lama, was controlled from computers based almost exclusively in China.
articles.lead_paragraph: TORONTO  A vast electronic spying operation has infiltrated computers and has stolen documents from hundreds of government and private offices around the world, including those of the Dalai Lama, Canadian researchers have concluded.

articles.headline: Is Facebook Growing Up Too Fast?
articles.snippet: Facebook soon expects to add its 200 millionth user. As it manages its growth, it must balance an increasingly disparate audience.
articles.abstract: Facebook soon expects to add its 200 millionth user. As it manages its growth, it must balance an increasingly disparate audience.
articles.lead_paragraph: WHEN Facebook signed up its 100 millionth member last August, its employees spread out in two parks in Palo Alto, Calif., for a huge barbecue. Sometime this week, this five-year-old start-up, born in a dorm room at Harvard, expects to register its 200 millionth user.

articles.headline: Don’t Come Crying to This Airline
articles.snippet: Spirit’s pay-for-extras strategy helps keep fares low. Some analysts say the airline may become more of an industry model during the economic downturn.
articles.abstract: Spirit’s pay-for-extras strategy helps keep fares low. Some analysts say the airline may become more of an industry model during the economic downturn.
articles.lead_paragraph: MIRAMAR, Fla.

articles.headline: Shareholders Who Act Like Owners
articles.snippet: The Louisiana Municipal Police Employee Retirement System is seeking answers on Chesapeake Energy’s $75 million bonus for its C.E.O.
articles.abstract: The Louisiana Municipal Police Employee Retirement System is seeking answers on Chesapeake Energy’s $75 million bonus for its C.E.O.
articles.lead_paragraph: HERE’S a study in contrasts: While Congress whips up outrage over compensation at the American International Group, a shareholder at Chesapeake Energy, whose directors awarded a $75 million bonus to its chief executive even as the company’s stock plummeted, is doing what responsible owners should do: quietly and methodically demanding answers and accountability from directors who awarded the handsome payout.

articles.headline: Speaking Freely, Biden Finds Influential Role
articles.snippet: President Obama has found the verbose vice president a useful contrarian in the course of decision-making.
articles.abstract: President Obama has found the verbose vice president a useful contrarian in the course of decision-making.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  When President Obama and Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. meet for their standing Friday lunch engagement, Mr. Obama always picks the cuisine  a subtle break from previous administrations in which the president and the vice president typically ordered off a menu, and a reminder, if any was needed, about who is in charge.

articles.headline: In Drug War, Mexico Fights Cartel and Itself
articles.snippet: Mexico has launched a war against drugs but it cannot fully rely on the institutions most needed to carry it out.
articles.abstract: Mexico has launched a war against drugs but it cannot fully rely on the institutions most needed to carry it out.
articles.lead_paragraph: REYNOSA, Mexico — An army convoy on the hunt for traffickers rolled out of its base recently in this border town under the control of the Gulf Cartel — and an ominous voice crackled over a two-way radio frequency to announce just that. The voice, belonging to a cartel spy, then broadcast the soldiers’ route through the city, turn by turn, using the same military language as the soldiers.

articles.headline: Some Online Shows Could Go Subscription-Only
articles.snippet: Cable TV providers are testing ways to restrict access to free shows on the Web to just their paying subscribers.
articles.abstract: Cable TV providers are testing ways to restrict access to free shows on the Web to just their paying subscribers.
articles.lead_paragraph: MILWAUKEE  In the last couple of years, the television industry has made a big push onto the Web, giving viewers hope that they might one day reach nirvana: every show ever made, available online for immediate free viewing.
articles.byline: By Brad Stone and Brian Stelter

articles.headline: Do-It-Yourself Magazines, Cheaply Slick
articles.snippet: Traditional printing houses charge thousands of dollars for a few hundred copies, but a new service hopes to cost less than making photocopies.
articles.abstract: Traditional printing houses charge thousands of dollars for a few hundred copies, but a new service hopes to cost less than making photocopies.
articles.lead_paragraph: PALO ALTO, Calif.  For anyone who has dreamed of creating his own glossy color magazine dedicated to a hobby like photography or travel, the high cost and hassle of printing has loomed as a big barrier. Traditional printing companies charge thousands of dollars upfront to fire up a press and produce a few hundred copies of a bound magazine.

articles.headline: The Steady Optimist Who Oversaw G.M.’s Decline
articles.snippet: Despite many challenges to his leadership, Rick Wagoner had managed to keep a firm grip on his job, until now.
articles.abstract: Despite many challenges to his leadership, Rick Wagoner had managed to keep a firm grip on his job, until now.
articles.lead_paragraph: DETROIT — In recent years, despite many challenges to his leadership of General Motors, Rick Wagoner had managed to keep a firm grip on his job, like hands wrapped tight around a steering wheel.

articles.headline: Star Lobbyist Closes Shop Amid F.B.I. Inquiry
articles.snippet: Many on Capitol Hill are wondering who will be ensnared in the investigation of Paul Magliocchetti.
articles.abstract: Many on Capitol Hill are wondering who will be ensnared in the investigation of Paul Magliocchetti.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  For most of the last three decades, the lobbyist Paul Magliocchetti might have been mistaken for an owner of the Alpine, a wood-paneled Italian restaurant across the Potomac River from Washington where he routinely presided over boisterous tables of lawmakers and their staff members.
articles.byline: By David D. Kirkpatrick and Charlie Savage

articles.headline: Fox News’s Mad, Apocalyptic, Tearful Rising Star
articles.snippet: Glenn Beck’s show has become wildly popular with a mix of moral lessons and outrage.
articles.abstract: Glenn Beck’s show has become wildly popular with a mix of moral lessons and outrage.
articles.lead_paragraph: “You are not alone,” Glenn Beck likes to say. For the disaffected and aggrieved Americans of the Obama era, he could not have picked a better rallying cry.
articles.byline: By Brian Stelter and Bill Carter

articles.headline: Cable News Stokes Political Fever
articles.snippet: Gorged on ratings from a historic election and still riding on leftover adrenaline, the cable networks have steadfastly remained in campaign mode.
articles.abstract: Gorged on ratings from a historic election and still riding on leftover adrenaline, the cable networks have steadfastly remained in campaign mode.
articles.lead_paragraph: MSNBC ran a countdown clock in preparation for the big event last Tuesday night. CNN’s run-up thrummed with portent, while a skeptical Fox News joined in the fervent speculation.

articles.headline: Setbacks in Bay Area Add to Pain for The Chronicle
articles.snippet: Geography, demographics and competition in the Bay Area are posing challenges beyond the headwinds facing all newspapers.
articles.abstract: Geography, demographics and competition in the Bay Area are posing challenges beyond the headwinds facing all newspapers.
articles.lead_paragraph: San Francisco offers a cast of offbeat stars  rockers, politicos, Internet moguls  playing for an audience with more than its share of affluent, literate people, on a stage rich in history, eccentricity and natural beauty. It sounds like a journalist’s dream, a great market for a news organization.

articles.headline: U.S. Lays Down Terms for Auto Bailout
articles.snippet: The White House asked Rick Wagoner to resign and instructed Chrysler to form a partnership with Fiat as a condition for new aid to be detailed Monday.
articles.abstract: The White House asked Rick Wagoner to resign and instructed Chrysler to form a partnership with Fiat as a condition for new aid to be detailed Monday.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The White House on Sunday pushed out the chairman of General Motors and instructed Chrysler to form a partnership with the Italian automaker Fiat within 30 days as conditions for receiving another much-needed round of government aid.
articles.byline: By Sheryl Gay Stolberg and Bill Vlasic

articles.headline: Rampage in Pakistan Shows Reach of Militants
articles.snippet: Pakistan’s inability to quell violence will complicate President Obama’s efforts to bring order to Afghanistan.
articles.abstract: Pakistan’s inability to quell violence will complicate President Obama’s efforts to bring order to Afghanistan.
articles.lead_paragraph: This article was reported by Sabrina Tavernise, Waqar Gillani and Salman Masood and written by Ms. Tavernise.
articles.byline: By Sabrina Tavernise, Waqar Gillani and Salman Masood
